text: If you did roughly the same work and the workplace culture was about the same, how much of a pay increase would it take you to leave one company for another? Other factors like company growth trajectory and career advancement notwithstanding.

elements.text: If you did roughly the same work and the workplace culture was about the same, how much of a pay increase would it take you to leave one company for another? Other factors like company growth trajectory and career advancement notwithstanding.

text: Depends what the normal pay increases look like at my current company? If its just COL increases each year (so… 3%ish) then I’d probably look for at least a 10-15% salary increase when I switch.

elements.text: Depends what the normal pay increases look like at my current company? If its just COL increases each year (so… 3%ish) then I’d probably look for at least a 10-15% salary increase when I switch.

text: I need someone to level with me. I believe I'm a decent writer.  I've been told my work is "impressive" but companies keep ghosting me through interviews and freelance work. Can someone check out my website and portfolio (posted to the site) and let me know if I have a future as a content marketer or not? Thanks. Here's my site: <https://www.allisonfrieden.com/>

elements.text: I need someone to level with me. I believe I'm a decent writer.  I've been told my work is "impressive" but companies keep ghosting me through interviews and freelance work. Can someone check out my website and portfolio (posted to the site) and let me know if I have a future as a content marketer or not? Thanks. Here's my site:

text: Hey Allison, your website and portfolio looks legit to me.

elements.text: Hey Allison, your website and portfolio looks legit to me.

text: Where in the process are people ghosting you?

elements.text: Where in the process are people ghosting you?

text: I’m sorry you’ve been ghosted, but it could definitely be about them and not you. It’s an uncertain time and I’m hearing about lots of content marketers getting ghosted right now due to all the volatility.

elements.text: I’m sorry you’ve been ghosted, but it could definitely be about them and not you. It’s an uncertain time and I’m hearing about lots of content marketers getting ghosted right now due to all the volatility.

text:
Plus one to being ghosted. I’ve had tons of false starts with projects. You’ve got to treat them like leads--a large percentage won’t work out to become clients--or at least, never on the timeline you expect.

Only thing I can suggest / think to analyze is: how easy are you making it for companies to work with you? Do you offer them clear follows ups with clear pricing and breakdowns? Do you proactively go to them with content suggestions so they don’t have to think? if the onus is on the client to think through something…they’ll stall…then delay…and just work with whoever makes it easiest. May be worth noodling on. ^^ I know I can scare people off with my depth at times, or flip flopping on what can be done. Clarity and brevity in pitches and pricing are our best friends

text: In the interest of total candor: I couldn’t find your writing samples or clips.  I also couldnt find anything about the results your content produced. Put that stuff front and center!

elements.text: In the interest of total candor: I couldn’t find your writing samples or clips.  I also couldnt find anything about the results your content produced. Put that stuff front and center!

text:
Your site is fantastic and you've worked with crazy good companies. 

Maybe show your portfolio on the homepage and what results they've generated. Also, customer testimonials helps a ton!

Anyways, I've just landed a role as the Head of Marketing at small (but funded) SaaS startup after 14 interviews & 8 weeks of struggling. I've been ghosted too and there are numerous reasons:

1) They can't afford you. This is probably the #1 reason companies reject but they don't tell you that upfront.

2) You come from a different industry. 30% of my interview rejections account for this. They simply want an expert in that industry. 

3) Ego. If they think you are a little too awesome, they tend to move away. In my experience, companies (or business heads) like to work with folks they think they can "control".

All in all, it's mostly them and not you. Keep trying and it'll happen. The perfect role is right around the corner.

3) Ego. If they think you are a little too awesome, they tend to move away. In my experience, companies (or business heads) like to work with folks they think they can "control".

All in all, it's mostly them and not you. Keep trying and it'll happen. The perfect role is right around the corner.

text: :heavy_plus_sign:1 to <@UJE5LQ2JC>’s comment - I was eventually able to find links to your clips, but it took some digging. Not sure everyone will be as persistent.

’s comment - I was eventually able to find links to your clips, but it took some digging. Not sure everyone will be as persistent.

text:
Oh i realized i focused my answer on freelancing vs interviewing for a full time position. That’s even HARDER to nail down. Agree with everything said here--there’s SO many hidden factors in hiring you never hear about. All you can do is ask for feedback (and hope it’s actually honest or helpful).

You could consider your interview answers to see if  anything there can could be improved (if you dont think this is your strong suit?). Then ask some peers or even people you know hiring for these roles what they’re looking for in these answers. Or, just write out your answers to common questions so they come out crisp and clear. (And ask for feedback.)

Best of luck!

Best of luck!

text: Thanks, everyone! I really appreciate all the advice and especially the candor. I can definitely bring my portfolio / clips to the front page and highlight the results from that a bit better. Right now, my portfolio is hosted on slideshare via a Powerpoint presentation. For some odd reason, SquareSpace won't allow me to embed that on my website - Are there any other sites I should look at to make this easier?

text: saw this in the Animalz newsletter today (TY <@UJ3K7N8GJ>) and felt relevant to this discussion: <https://www.atlassian.com/blog/leadership/voluntary-demotion>

attachments.title: Could a voluntary demotion be your best career move? - Work Life by Atlassian
attachments.text: Why opting out of a management role isn't the career-killer it used to be. (Plus, how execs can prevent a wave of voluntary demotions at their company.)
attachments.fallback: Work Life by Atlassian: Could a voluntary demotion be your best career move? - Work Life by Atlassian

elements.text: saw this in the Animalz newsletter today (TY
) and felt relevant to this discussion:

text: Honestly, I'd pull it out of that format entirely. A slide deck isn't the best way to show a portfolio, especially when its just a list of hyperlinks and isn't visual at all. I'd think about completely reformatting it, as well as slimming it down. It might be nice to have the comprehensive portfolio linked somewhere, but for your main portfolio you should pick the best examples of your work as there's no way people are going to look through all those links you have. You could select the best example or three per industry, per content stream, or another way to organize that fits your work and would be helpful to your target audience. In addition, showing off fewer pieces of work would let you add some context to each piece as to what the goal was and what the results of the piece were, if you wanted to do that. If the person looks through your portfolio and wants more samples, then you could handpick some that align with their industry/topics or the type of content they are looking for. That way it's tailored to them and they can easily see that you can provide what they need

I'd think about completely reformatting it, as well as slimming it down. It might be nice to have the comprehensive portfolio linked somewhere, but for your main portfolio you should pick the best examples of your work as there's no way people are going to look through all those links you have. You could select the best example or three per industry, per content stream, or another way to organize that fits your work and would be helpful to your target audience. In addition, showing off fewer pieces of work would let you add some context to each piece as to what the goal was and what the results of the piece were, if you wanted to do that. If the person looks through your portfolio and wants more samples, then you could handpick some that align with their industry/topics or the type of content they are looking for. That way it's tailored to them and they can easily see that you can provide what they need

text:
As a hiring manager, I don’t care too much about format or the look of a portfolio. If it’s nice, that helps. But honestly Send me 5-10 relevant links in an email. I’m using that to decide if you’re worth an interview. If someone has a better portfolio or a pretty one, but the writing isn’t great, it’s a non-starter. 

It sounds like whatever you’re doing now is getting you interviews. Fussing over the format may not be the best use of your time compared to doing more outreach, networking, getting referrals and brushing up in interview skills. (Just my two cents)

text: Is there such thing as a style editor for content? My wife can take my dry writing and make it way more entertaining and engaging. I'm trying to help her find some editing gigs doing the same thing for others, but I'm having a hard time figuring out what to call it.

elements.text: Is there such thing as a style editor for content? My wife can take my dry writing and make it way more entertaining and engaging. I'm trying to help her find some editing gigs doing the same thing for others, but I'm having a hard time figuring out what to call it.

text: Hi David! Might have to call it editing but use her content styling skills to write a short pitch that explains it more than an explanation would!

elements.text: Hi David! Might have to call it editing but use her content styling skills to write a short pitch that explains it more than an explanation would!

text: And of course, a portfolio replete with before-after shots of the same write-ups will do the rest!

elements.text: And of course, a portfolio replete with before-after shots of the same write-ups will do the rest!
